clusters.title: ‘Better and cheaper’: the case for prostate cancer screening among black men
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘Better and cheaper’: the case for prostate cancer screening among black men

items.title: ‘Better and cheaper’: the case for prostate cancer screening among black men
items.standfirst: Decision over routine PSA testing is due at end of this month, though some feel the supporting data is unclearJunior Hemans was having a routine health check in 2014 when he was diagnosed with prostate cancer, at the age of 51. He knew there was an increased risk of the disease in black men so asked to have a prostate specific antigen (PSA) test, which was not initially included.“And when I went, they said I had a raised PSA level for my age,” Hemans said. “[The diagnosis] was a shock … because I had no symptoms.” Continue reading...
items.content: Decision over routine PSA testing is due at end of this month, though some feel the supporting data is unclearJunior Hemans was having a routine health check in 2014 when he was diagnosed with prostate cancer, at the age of 51. He knew there was an increased risk of the disease in black men so asked to have a prostate specific antigen (PSA) test, which was not initially included.“And when I went, they said I had a raised PSA level for my age,” Hemans said. “[The diagnosis] was a shock … because I had no symptoms.” Continue reading...

clusters.title: UK weather: amber cold health alerts issued for northern England
clusters.neutral_headline: UK Issues Cold Health Alerts for Northern England

items.title: UK weather: amber cold health alerts issued for northern England
items.standfirst: Warnings in place until 8am Saturday, with sub-zero overnight temperatures also expected to disrupt transportAmber cold health alerts have been issued for northern England amid warnings of sub-zero overnight temperatures this week.The UK Health Security Agency issued amber warnings for north-east and north-west England, and Yorkshire and the Humber. The alerts indicate an “increase in risk to health for individuals aged over 65 years or those with pre-existing health conditions, including respiratory and cardiovascular diseases” as well as greater risk of disruptions to roads and public transport. Continue reading...

The alerts indicate an “increase in risk to health for individuals aged over 65 years or those with pre-existing health conditions, including respiratory and cardiovascular diseases” as well as greater risk of disruptions to roads and public transport. Continue reading...

ai_summary: UKHSA issued amber warnings for north-east, north-west England, and Yorkshire and the Humber.
Alerts indicate increased health risk for those over 65 or with pre-existing conditions.
Respiratory and cardiovascular diseases are included in the pre-existing conditions.
Disruptions to roads and public transport are also a potential risk.
Warnings are in place until 8 AM Saturday, with sub-zero temperatures expected.

clusters.title: Stephen Dawson obituary
clusters.neutral_headline: Stephen Dawson Obituary: A Urologist in the AIDS Era

items.title: Stephen Dawson obituary
items.standfirst: My friend Stephen Dawson, who has died of cancer aged 78, had the questionable luck of being a newly minted urologist when Aids first struck in London in the early 1980s.The son of Philip, a nuclear physicist at the Atomic Energy Research Establishment at Harwell, and May, a housewife, Steve was born in London, went to King Alfred’s school, Wantage, and studied medicine at University College Hospital before qualifying as a fellow of the Royal College of Physicians in the late 70s. The decade that followed was both clinically fascinating and emotionally challenging. Continue reading...
items.content: My friend Stephen Dawson, who has died of cancer aged 78, had the questionable luck of being a newly minted urologist when Aids first struck in London in the early 1980s.The son of Philip, a nuclear physicist at the Atomic Energy Research Establishment at Harwell, and May, a housewife, Steve was born in London, went to King Alfred’s school, Wantage, and studied medicine at University College Hospital before qualifying as a fellow of the Royal College of Physicians in the late 70s. The decade that followed was both clinically fascinating and emotionally challenging. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Stephen Dawson died of cancer at age 78, a urologist when AIDS emerged.
He was the son of a nuclear physicist and a housewife.
Dawson studied medicine at University College Hospital.
He qualified as a fellow of the Royal College of Physicians in the late 70s.
The following decade was clinically fascinating and emotionally challenging.

clusters.title: Are you stuck in ordinary - but devastating - narcissism? There is a way out
clusters.neutral_headline: Overcoming Narcissism: Finding Meaningful Therapy

items.title: Are you stuck in ordinary - but devastating - narcissism? There is a way out
items.standfirst: Meaningful therapy offers a path past our worst impulses. We should be fighting for it to be available for everyoneWhen I picture what a good life means to me, I feel a tension in my chest. I see my daughter and my husband and I feel the profound fulfilment of being exactly where I need to be, tightened by the terror that life is so fragile and I cannot protect them from that reality. Then a memory: lying on my analyst’s couch and describing a feeling of hollowness inside that I felt deeply ashamed of, and her listening and thinking and understanding – and my noticing that while I felt horror and repulsion, she didn’t seem to. Next: different walks around different parks with different friends, each with the same feeling of being warmed from the inside out; also, bumping into neighbours at the playground and feeling a part of my community. I remember powerful moments with my patients, who have felt understood, by me and within themselves. And I think of the moving messages from readers who have got in touch, sharing precious stories from their lives.People often think that psychoanalysis and its NHS-friendly grandchild, psychodynamic psychotherapy, are all about looking inwards. And it’s true – good therapy should give us the time and space, the frame and the containment, to look inside and listen to ourselves. Continue reading...
items.content: Meaningful therapy offers a path past our worst impulses. We should be fighting for it to be available for everyoneWhen I picture what a good life means to me, I feel a tension in my chest. I see my daughter and my husband and I feel the profound fulfilment of being exactly where I need to be, tightened by the terror that life is so fragile and I cannot protect them from that reality. Then a memory: lying on my analyst’s couch and describing a feeling of hollowness inside that I felt deeply ashamed of, and her listening and thinking and understanding – and my noticing that while I felt horror and repulsion, she didn’t seem to. Next: different walks around different parks with different friends, each with the same feeling of being warmed from the inside out; also, bumping into neighbours at the playground and feeling a part of my community. I remember powerful moments with my patients, who have felt understood, by me and within themselves. And I think of the moving messages from readers who have got in touch, sharing precious stories from their lives.People often think that psychoanalysis and its NHS-friendly grandchild, psychodynamic psychotherapy, are all about looking inwards. And it’s true – good therapy should give us the time and space, the frame and the containment, to look inside and listen to ourselves. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author describes a feeling of hollowness and shame, seeking therapy.
Therapy provides space to look inward and listen to oneself.
Good therapy offers time and containment for self-reflection.
The author finds fulfillment in family and community connections.
Readers share stories, highlighting the value of understanding.

clusters.title: The one change that worked: I had Sad and felt desperate – until a scientist gave me some priceless advice
clusters.neutral_headline: One Change That Worked: Advice for Seasonal Affective Disorder

items.title: The one change that worked: I had Sad and felt desperate – until a scientist gave me some priceless advice
items.standfirst: Since I was a teenager I had struggled in winter, experiencing excessive tiredness and low mood. A specific instruction lifted the gloomI’m pretty sure I must be half human, half plant – how else to explain why I need the light to thrive? During the brighter seasons I feel fine, but when winter comes and the light begins to fade, I start drooping.I have struggled with seasonal affective disorder (Sad) since I was a teenager. The symptoms of Sad are similar to regular depression, with low moods and lethargy, and can be equally debilitating. Over the years I’ve experienced the full Sad spectrum, from moments of excessive tiredness and carb cravings (yes, those are official Sad symptoms), to a low point of breaking down crying on the kitchen floor after school because it was so cold, dark and bleak. Continue reading...
items.content: Since I was a teenager I had struggled in winter, experiencing excessive tiredness and low mood. A specific instruction lifted the gloomI’m pretty sure I must be half human, half plant – how else to explain why I need the light to thrive? During the brighter seasons I feel fine, but when winter comes and the light begins to fade, I start drooping.I have struggled with seasonal affective disorder (Sad) since I was a teenager. The symptoms of Sad are similar to regular depression, with low moods and lethargy, and can be equally debilitating. Over the years I’ve experienced the full Sad spectrum, from moments of excessive tiredness and carb cravings (yes, those are official Sad symptoms), to a low point of breaking down crying on the kitchen floor after school because it was so cold, dark and bleak. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author struggled with Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD) since teenage years.
Symptoms include low mood, lethargy, and excessive tiredness.
The author experienced various SAD symptoms, including carb cravings.
A scientist gave specific advice that lifted the author's gloom.
The author feels better during brighter seasons, struggling in winter.

clusters.title: Is it true that … you burn more fat by working out on an empty stomach?
clusters.neutral_headline: Exercising on an Empty Stomach: Does It Burn More Fat?

items.title: Is it true that … you burn more fat by working out on an empty stomach?
items.standfirst: There are modest benefits to exercising on an empty stomach, but it’s more important to burn more energy than you’re consuming‘There’s an element of truth to that,” says Javier Gonzalez, a professor of nutrition and metabolism at the University of Bath. “When we exercise, we’re always burning a mix of fuels – mainly carbohydrates and fat. If you’ve fasted overnight, you’ll generally burn a bit more fat and less carbohydrate than if you’d eaten breakfast, especially one high in carbs.” But that doesn’t mean fasted workouts are better for weight loss.“We can only store a small amount of carbohydrate as glycogen in our muscles and liver. Any extra energy – from carbs, fat or protein – eventually gets stored as body fat. So to lose fat, you need to be in an energy deficit: burning more energy than you consume. If you’re not, it doesn’t matter whether you’re fasted or fed – your body balances things out over time,” says Gonzalez. Continue reading...
items.content: There are modest benefits to exercising on an empty stomach, but it’s more important to burn more energy than you’re consuming‘There’s an element of truth to that,” says Javier Gonzalez, a professor of nutrition and metabolism at the University of Bath. “When we exercise, we’re always burning a mix of fuels – mainly carbohydrates and fat. If you’ve fasted overnight, you’ll generally burn a bit more fat and less carbohydrate than if you’d eaten breakfast, especially one high in carbs.” But that doesn’t mean fasted workouts are better for weight loss.“We can only store a small amount of carbohydrate as glycogen in our muscles and liver. Any extra energy – from carbs, fat or protein – eventually gets stored as body fat. So to lose fat, you need to be in an energy deficit: burning more energy than you consume. If you’re not, it doesn’t matter whether you’re fasted or fed – your body balances things out over time,” says Gonzalez. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Exercising on an empty stomach has modest benefits, according to a professor.
Fasted workouts burn more fat and less carbohydrates, especially without breakfast.
To lose fat, one must be in an energy deficit, burning more than consuming.
The body balances energy intake and expenditure over time.
Any extra energy gets stored as body fat.

clusters.title: ‘I’d run down the road thinking I was God’: a day at the cannabis psychosis clinic
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘I’d run down the road thinking I was God’: a day at the cannabis psychosis clinic

items.title: ‘I’d run down the road thinking I was God’: a day at the cannabis psychosis clinic
items.standfirst: Katie hears voices and has been sectioned 50 times. Isiah became paranoid and tried to kill himself. Both link their illness to cannabis – and the drug is getting more and more potent. Is a tiny London clinic showing the way forward?It’s two years since Isiah found himself on the roof of a south London shopping centre, about to jump. “I was very done,” he says of that night in November 2023. “It felt there was no other route or option. First, I did a walk around everywhere important to me: primary school, secondary, college.” Then he headed to Lewisham shopping centre. “I remember my head was telling me: ‘You’re probably better off doing this.’”He was exhausted by his paranoia, which had grown in tandem with a cannabis habit. Now 29, he first tried marijuana at 14, becoming a daily user by 17. At university, studying event management during the pandemic, he smoked more “because this is how you meet people”, but remembers growing “feelings of suspiciousness”, first towards his housemates, then to his workmates at a part-time office job. He struggled to sleep, “started to isolate”, and cannabis became a way to cope. In the end, smoking three joints a day, he felt he could trust no one. Continue reading...
items.content: Katie hears voices and has been sectioned 50 times. Isiah became paranoid and tried to kill himself. Both link their illness to cannabis – and the drug is getting more and more potent. Is a tiny London clinic showing the way forward?It’s two years since Isiah found himself on the roof of a south London shopping centre, about to jump. “I was very done,” he says of that night in November 2023. “It felt there was no other route or option. First, I did a walk around everywhere important to me: primary school, secondary, college.” Then he headed to Lewisham shopping centre. “I remember my head was telling me: ‘You’re probably better off doing this.’”He was exhausted by his paranoia, which had grown in tandem with a cannabis habit. Now 29, he first tried marijuana at 14, becoming a daily user by 17. At university, studying event management during the pandemic, he smoked more “because this is how you meet people”, but remembers growing “feelings of suspiciousness”, first towards his housemates, then to his workmates at a part-time office job. He struggled to sleep, “started to isolate”, and cannabis became a way to cope. In the end, smoking three joints a day, he felt he could trust no one. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Katie hears voices and has been sectioned 50 times.
Isiah became paranoid and attempted suicide.
Both link their illness to cannabis use.
The drug is getting more and more potent.
A tiny London clinic may be showing the way forward.

clusters.title: Want to avoid anxiety, headaches and constipation? Try giving up on your goals | Emma Beddington
clusters.neutral_headline: Want to avoid anxiety, headaches and constipation? Try giving up on your goals

items.title: Want to avoid anxiety, headaches and constipation? Try giving up on your goals | Emma Beddington
items.standfirst: We’re taught from infancy that perseverance is a moral virtue and persistence pays. But what if quitters are happier and healthier?Have you ever heard yourself saying “I’m going to do this if it kills me”? As the pensioners at my gym can attest, it’s what I hiss every time I’m there, attempting slowly and laboriously to get myself a millimetre closer to doing the splits.But what if it actually is killing me? Not the groin strain, problematic as that is, but because I’ve just read in New Scientist that giving up is good for you, while grinding on isn’t. One study showed that people who “struggled to disengage from unfulfilling goals” had higher levels of cortisol and inflammatory molecules. “The result,” the article explained, “could be a heightened susceptibility to all kinds of conditions, including cardiovascular disease and Alzheimer’s.” In addition, “goal disengagement” – giving up – correlated with a lower risk of headaches, constipation and eczema; it may even protect against infection. Of 131 older adults, those who scored highly on a giving up scale (asking how easily they stopped fixating on unfulfilling goals and pivoted to others) got fewer colds. Continue reading...
items.content: We’re taught from infancy that perseverance is a moral virtue and persistence pays. But what if quitters are happier and healthier?Have you ever heard yourself saying “I’m going to do this if it kills me”? As the pensioners at my gym can attest, it’s what I hiss every time I’m there, attempting slowly and laboriously to get myself a millimetre closer to doing the splits.But what if it actually is killing me? Not the groin strain, problematic as that is, but because I’ve just read in New Scientist that giving up is good for you, while grinding on isn’t. One study showed that people who “struggled to disengage from unfulfilling goals” had higher levels of cortisol and inflammatory molecules. “The result,” the article explained, “could be a heightened susceptibility to all kinds of conditions, including cardiovascular disease and Alzheimer’s.” In addition, “goal disengagement” – giving up – correlated with a lower risk of headaches, constipation and eczema; it may even protect against infection. Of 131 older adults, those who scored highly on a giving up scale (asking how easily they stopped fixating on unfulfilling goals and pivoted to others) got fewer colds. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A New Scientist article suggests giving up on unfulfilling goals is beneficial for health.
People struggling to disengage from unfulfilling goals showed higher cortisol and inflammatory molecules.
"Goal disengagement" correlated with lower risk of headaches, constipation, and eczema.
Giving up may protect against infection, as seen in a study of older adults.
Those who easily stopped fixating on unfulfilling goals got fewer colds.

clusters.title: Everything I wish I’d known before I decided to freeze my eggs at 36
clusters.neutral_headline: Everything I wish I’d known before I decided to freeze my eggs at 36: More and more people are turning to egg freezing to increase their chances of becoming a parent. Here’s what you need to know if you’re considering it – from the hidden costs to the chances of success

items.title: Everything I wish I’d known before I decided to freeze my eggs at 36
items.standfirst: More and more people are turning to egg freezing to increase their chances of becoming a parent. Here’s what you need to know if you’re considering it – from the hidden costs to the chances of successWhen I first told my mother I was freezing my eggs, she asked: “So my grandchildren are going to be stored next to some Häagen-Dazs?” (Very funny, Mum.) I’m one of an increasing number of women in the UK who have chosen to put their eggs on ice in order to preserve their fertility, although this does – as discussed later – have clear limitations.According to the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA), the UK’s regulator for the fertility industry, there was a 170% increase in the number of egg freezing cycles between 2019 and 2023. The technology has been around since the 80s, but became more accessible in the 00s with vitrification, a flash-freezing technique. Now, celebrities such as Florence Pugh and Michaela Coel openly discuss their experiences of it, and companies such as Meta, Spotify and Goldman Sachs subsidise the procedure for employees. Continue reading...
items.content: More and more people are turning to egg freezing to increase their chances of becoming a parent. Here’s what you need to know if you’re considering it – from the hidden costs to the chances of successWhen I first told my mother I was freezing my eggs, she asked: “So my grandchildren are going to be stored next to some Häagen-Dazs?” (Very funny, Mum.) I’m one of an increasing number of women in the UK who have chosen to put their eggs on ice in order to preserve their fertility, although this does – as discussed later – have clear limitations.According to the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA), the UK’s regulator for the fertility industry, there was a 170% increase in the number of egg freezing cycles between 2019 and 2023. The technology has been around since the 80s, but became more accessible in the 00s with vitrification, a flash-freezing technique. Now, celebrities such as Florence Pugh and Michaela Coel openly discuss their experiences of it, and companies such as Meta, Spotify and Goldman Sachs subsidise the procedure for employees. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Egg freezing is increasingly popular in the UK to preserve fertility, with limitations.
The HFEA reported a 170% increase in egg freezing cycles between 2019 and 2023.
Vitrification, a flash-freezing technique, made egg freezing more accessible in the 2000s.
Celebrities and companies like Meta subsidize egg freezing for employees.
The article discusses hidden costs and success chances of egg freezing.
